articles.title: The Papers:  'Peace within reach' and 'A moment of shared hope'
articles.summary: The ceasefire negotiations for the Israel-Gaza war and celebrations of peace dominate Friday's papers.
articles.content:
'Peace within reach' and 'A moment of shared hope'

3 hours ago Share Save Share Save

BBC The ceasefire negotiations over the Israel-Gaza war and first celebrations of peace dominate Friday's papers. Metro goes with "peace within reach at last" to mark the "dramatic breakthrough in the Middle East". The agreement comes after "indirect talks in the Egyptian resort of Sharm el-Sheikh". US President Donald Trump thinks it will be "a lasting peace, hopefully an everlasting peace", the paper writes.

"'We have peace in the Middle East'," heralds The Daily Telegraph. The quote from Trump tops the paper along with a picture of the man himself grinning in the Oval Office. Also on its front page, the NHS is in a "state of emergency", according to doctors. In another story, the paper follows up the fallout from the collapsed case of two men accused of spying for China. It says that Prime Minister Sir Keir Starmer's national security adviser, Jonathan Powell, "suppressed a major Whitehall investigation into Chinese spying after lobbying from the Treasury". Treasury officials had said "comprehensive" analysis of China's influence in Britain "could damage trade and investment links", according to The Telegraph.

The Financial Times also leads with the Middle East, saying "Israel and Hamas agree to first phase of US-led ceasefire plan for Gaza war". In Gaza, people "cheered on the rubble-strewn streets" and in Israel "tears of joy erupted" in Hostages' Square. Elsewhere, former Prime Minister Rishi Sunak is "to accept senior advisory roles at Microsoft and AI start-up Anthropic".

For The Guardian it is "celebrations after Hamas and Israel agree first phase of deal". It notes that Trump has said the hostages could be released by "Monday or Tuesday". The paper also features the news of former Radio 1 DJ Tim Westwood having been charged with four counts of rape. The 68-year-old has also been charged with nine counts of indecent assault and two counts of sexual assault. The charges relate to seven women.

The i Paper is topped by the "ceasefire deal for Gaza" which will "begin within 24 hours of cabinet approval". Israel is "to withdraw troops and hostages set for release", it writes as "world leaders express hope". Meanwhile, Iran has warned the international community to "remain vigilant against 'deception and breach of commitments' by Israel".

It is "a moment of shared hope" for the Daily Mirror as it shares parallel photos of children atop shoulders in Gaza and Tel Aviv. It notes the "relief, tears and cautious optimism" that come "after two years of unrelenting horror".

Photos of "thrilled crowds" in Gaza and Israel lead the Daily Express as they "unite in celebrating" "Trump's peace". A woman is pictured flinging her arms open in Israel and a young boy holds his arms in the air in Gaza amongst a crowd.

The Mail praises Trump's Middle East diplomacy by declaring "blessed is the peacemaker" while "virtue-signalling liberals" like Sir Keir Starmer and French President Emmanuel Macron are dubbed "utterly pointless". A snap of a woman holding a baby is accompanied by her tale. "Friends are horrified that I breastfed my grandchildren", she is quoted as saying, but "I don't regret it one bit".

The Times echoes most fronts with "Trump celebrates art of the 'everlasting peace' deal". Catherine, Princess of Wales, also makes its top stories as she "picks up pen to warn of dangers of screen time". The paper also reports that parents who were jailed over the deaths of their babies are appealing against their convictions after "doubt cast on 'shaken baby' expert". Forensic expert Professor David Mangham is now the subject of a General Medical Council inquiry, the paper says.

The Sun is topped by an "exclusive" on "Posh on marriage". Lady Beckham is quoted as saying her husband Sir David is "smart, good-looking and funny.. but even David Beckham snores!"

The Daily Star headlines on Madeleine McCann's sister Amelie who has told of her "stalker hell" in an ongoing court case. Two women are on trial accused of stalking the parents of Madeleine, who disappeared on 3 May 2007 in Portugal. On Gaza, the paper describes the situation as a "fragile peace".
articles.reasoning: The article reports a major breakthrough in ceasefire negotiations between Israel and Hamas, leading to a potential lasting peace in the Middle East. This development has broad significance for millions affected by the conflict, offering hope and relief after prolonged violence. The story is focused on this single, impactful event and provides detailed context about the ceasefire agreement and public reactions.
articles.personality_title: Israel and Hamas agree on ceasefire, sparking hope for peace
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – The long conflict between Israel and Hamas has caused much suffering and violence in the Middle East, affecting millions of people. For years, efforts to stop the fighting have faced many challenges.

**What happened** – Recently, Israel and Hamas agreed to a ceasefire after talks held indirectly in Egypt’s resort city, Sharm el-Sheikh. The deal was announced this week and is the first phase of a US-led peace plan. Celebrations broke out in both Gaza and Israel, with people showing relief and hope for the future. US President Donald Trump called it a "dramatic breakthrough" and expressed hope it would lead to lasting peace.

**Impact** – This ceasefire is important because it could stop the violence that has caused so much pain and loss on both sides. The agreement also includes the withdrawal of Israeli troops and the release of hostages, which are key steps toward peace. People in the region, including children, have shown cautious optimism after years of conflict.

**What's next step** – The ceasefire will begin once the Israeli cabinet approves it, expected within 24 hours. Leaders around the world are watching closely and hoping the peace will hold. Meanwhile, there are warnings to stay careful and watch for any possible breaches of the agreement.

**One-sentence takeaway** – After years of conflict, Israel and Hamas have agreed to a ceasefire that brings new hope for peace and relief to people in the Middle East.
articles.personality_title_fr: Israël et le Hamas s'accordent sur un cessez-le-feu, suscitant l'espoir de paix
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Le conflit long et violent entre Israël et le Hamas a causé beaucoup de souffrances au Moyen-Orient, touchant des millions de personnes. Pendant des années, les efforts pour arrêter les combats ont rencontré de nombreux obstacles.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Récemment, Israël et le Hamas ont accepté un cessez-le-feu après des discussions indirectes à Sharm el-Sheikh, en Égypte. Cet accord est la première étape d’un plan de paix dirigé par les États-Unis. Des célébrations ont eu lieu à Gaza et en Israël, avec un sentiment de soulagement et d’espoir. Le président américain Donald Trump a parlé d’un « progrès spectaculaire » et espère une paix durable.

**Impact** – Ce cessez-le-feu est important car il pourrait mettre fin à la violence qui a causé tant de pertes des deux côtés. L’accord prévoit aussi le retrait des troupes israéliennes et la libération d’otages, des étapes clés pour la paix. Les habitants, y compris les enfants, montrent un optimisme prudent après des années de conflit.

**Prochaine étape** – Le cessez-le-feu commencera dès l’approbation du cabinet israélien, prévue sous 24 heures. Les dirigeants mondiaux suivent la situation avec attention en espérant que la paix dure. En même temps, des avertissements appellent à rester vigilants face à d’éventuelles violations.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Après des années de conflit, Israël et le Hamas ont accepté un cessez-le-feu qui apporte un nouvel espoir de paix et de soulagement au Moyen-Orient.
articles.personality_title_es: Israel y Hamas acuerdan un alto el fuego que genera esperanza de paz
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – El largo conflicto entre Israel y Hamas ha causado mucho sufrimiento y violencia en el Medio Oriente, afectando a millones de personas. Durante años, los esfuerzos para detener los combates enfrentaron muchos desafíos.

**Qué pasó** – Recientemente, Israel y Hamas acordaron un alto el fuego tras conversaciones indirectas en Sharm el-Sheikh, Egipto. El acuerdo es la primera fase de un plan de paz liderado por Estados Unidos. En Gaza e Israel, la gente celebró mostrando alivio y esperanza. El presidente estadounidense Donald Trump llamó a este avance "un gran progreso" y expresó su deseo de una paz duradera.

**Impacto** – Este alto el fuego es importante porque podría detener la violencia que ha causado tanto dolor y pérdidas en ambos lados. El acuerdo también incluye la retirada de tropas israelíes y la liberación de rehenes, pasos clave hacia la paz. La gente, incluidos los niños, muestra un optimismo cauteloso después de años de conflicto.

**Próximo paso** – El alto el fuego comenzará cuando el gabinete israelí lo apruebe, lo que se espera dentro de 24 horas. Líderes de todo el mundo observan con atención y esperan que la paz se mantenga. Mientras tanto, hay advertencias para mantenerse vigilantes ante posibles incumplimientos.

**Conclusión en una frase** – Tras años de conflicto, Israel y Hamas han acordado un alto el fuego que brinda nueva esperanza de paz y alivio a la gente del Medio Oriente.

articles.title: Youth plaintiffs test out a new legal strategy to counter Trump’s support for fossil fuels
articles.summary:
In spring of this year, the nonprofit law firm Our Children’s Trust invited Miko Vergun, a plaintiff in the landmark 2015 federal youth climate lawsuit Juliana v. United States, to join a lawsuit challenging the constitutionality of Trump’s three executive orders, “Unleashing American Energy,” “Declaring a National Energy Emergency” and “Reinvigorating America’s Beautiful Clean Coal Industry.”

The Juliana case asked the court to order the government to prepare and implement a plan to fix climate change. This time, plaintiffs are seeking a narrower remedy.
articles.content:
Miko Vergun, a plaintiff in the landmark 2015 federal youth climate lawsuit Juliana v. United States, which questioned the constitutionality of 50 years of government support for fossil fuels, wasn’t surprised on the first day of President Donald Trump’s second term when he issued three executive orders meant to clear the way for the drilling of more oil and gas and the mining of more coal in the name of energy security. She was nevertheless “disheartened” that her government planned to redouble its support of fossil fuels even in light of the harm climate change was causing.

Then three months later, she learned that the U.S. Supreme Court would not reconsider its 2020 dismissal of Juliana — after a decade, her case was over. “After Juliana, truthfully, I had given up hope,” she told Grist.

The Juliana case was the first in a series of lawsuits brought by the nonprofit law firm Our Children’s Trust on behalf of youth plaintiffs. In August 2023, they won their case against Montana, which argued for a “fundamental constitutional right to a clean and healthful environment,” and now the state must consider greenhouse gas emissions and their impacts in its permitting process. In 2024, the state of Hawaiʻi settled a case brought by Our Children’s Trust, agreeing to decarbonize its transportation system and reach zero emissions by 2045.

In spring of this year, Our Children’s Trust invited Vergun to join another lawsuit — challenging the constitutionality of Trump’s three executive orders, “Unleashing American Energy,” “Declaring a National Energy Emergency” and “Reinvigorating America’s Beautiful Clean Coal Industry.”

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

Vergun had her doubts. “It’s really easy to take a nihilistic view, especially in these uncertain times,” she told Grist. “But I woke up one day, and I was like, ‘Yeah, I want to join.’”

In September, after the initial court proceedings, Vergun, her lawyers, and 21 other plaintiffs, ages 7 to 25, met in a Missoula, Montana, courthouse for the evidentiary hearing in a new case, Lighthiser v. Trump. The hearing was a sort of mini-trial in which both sides were given a chance to present their arguments and to question witnesses. The testimony was both emblematic of Our Children’s Trust’s approach and indicative of their evolving strategy.

A protester holds a sign with a quote from Eva Lighthiser, the lead plaintiff in Lighthiser v. Trump. Photo by Alex Wroblewski / AFP via Getty Images

On the first day of the hearing, gray fog cloaked downtown Missoula, but the young plaintiffs bubbled with excitement as they strode toward the red-brick courthouse through a pathway festooned with marigolds. About 100 supporters carrying signs cheered as they entered the courthouse and filed up to the second floor. Once everyone settled into the long wooden rows facing the judge’s bench, Julia Olson, the lead attorney for the plaintiffs, rose for her opening statement. “This case asks a fundamental question,” she said. “Does the United States Constitution guard against abuses of power by executive order that deprive children and youth of their fundamental rights to life and to their liberties?”

It’s a question that, according to Mary Wood, professor of law at the University of Oregon, distinguishes the legal strategy in Lighthiser from Juliana. The earlier case asked the court to order the government to prepare and implement a plan to fix climate change. This time, plaintiffs are seeking a narrower remedy — an injunction to stop implementation of the three specific executive orders. “It’s a discrete request in the here and now designed to prevent further, ongoing harm,” Wood said.

To support our nonprofit environmental journalism, please consider disabling your ad-blocker to allow ads on Grist. Here's How

But it wasn’t a difference the government lawyers conceded. “Here we are back again, attempting to deal with fundamentally the same legal claim all over again,” Department of Justice attorney Michael Sawyer said in his opening argument. The plaintiffs, he said, want the courts to “step in and exercise general supervision over the nation’s energy policy.”

Since the defendants declined to call any witnesses, Our Children’s Trust had two days to make their case. They began with young plaintiffs. First Olson called to the stand Joseph Lee of Fullerton, California, a wiry 19-year-old with long bangs and glasses wearing a dark suit and sneakers. He raised his right hand and became the first youth in history to testify in a federal youth climate case against the U.S. — something that Our Children’s Trust had been working toward for more than a decade. Sitting in the witness stand, Lee recounted growing up near an oil refinery and developing asthma; how heat, humidity, and wildfire smoke made it feel like his lungs were filled with water; how he has been hospitalized multiple times, once even surgically intubated during a heat wave. “I’m not sure if I can go on,” he said.

Olson asked him: “Will stopping the EOs end climate change?”

“No,” he replied. “But it will stop it from getting worse.”

In cross-examination, DOJ attorney Erik Van de Stouwe noted the lack of air conditioning in Lee’s dorm at UC San Diego and how that must aggravate his asthma. “But you didn’t take legal action against the State of California, right?

“To categorize the years of struggles I’ve had into a mere issue of air conditioning is something that’s hurtful,” Lee replied.

The second witness, Jorja M., 17, told the court about grabbing her stuffed animals when a wildfire threatened her home in Livingston, Montana. She testified about a 2022 flood that crept up to the door of her family’s vet clinic, “even though we are not on a floodplain.” She described black coal dust from trains coating her home and irritating her nose, throat, and lungs. The coal came from Colstrip, a plant that was scheduled to close and will now remain open following the Trump executive orders.

As the government’s attorney Miranda Jensen approached the witness stand, Jorja shifted nervously in her seat. “You testified that you have three horses, right?” Jensen asked.

“Yes,” Jorja answered.

“And you’re aware that raising horses contributes to global warming?”

“I am aware of that, yes.”

“Are you concerned by the emissions that your horses contribute to the problem?”

Gasps of exasperation arose from the audience.

“I think that having three horses has minimal emissions,” Jorja said.

After answering more questions, Jorja returned to her seat in the gallery and caught eyes with Avery McRae, the next plaintiff to testify. They smiled knowingly at each other.

After she was sworn in as the next witness, Olson asked McRae, 20, to describe struggling to care for her horse and other farm animals during wildfires and heat waves that have been plaguing Oregon. McRae remembered “coughing” and “feeling awful.” As she continued on with her testimony, McRae described moving to Florida for college, only to walk right into a different sort of climate disaster: In her first three years, she had to evacuate for three massive hurricanes. “The whole campus was inundated with sea water,” she said, her voice calm but tinged with anger. She had to pay for an Airbnb, huddle in a closet during a tornado warning, and fly home to attend class on Zoom for five weeks.

In the cross-examination, the government lawyer clarified which climate disasters happened before Trump signed the executive orders and which happened after.

Olson had a chance to redirect.

“Are you bringing this case to remedy past injuries?” she asked.

Avery answered, “No.”

“Are you asking the court to provide the remedy of stopping the EOs?”

“Yes.”

With those testimonies, Our Children’s Trust had begun to lay out its basic argument — that its clients are suffering from climate change and Trump’s executive orders will make it worse, a violation of their constitutional rights to life and liberty. Their legal strategy for the rest of the hearing depended heavily on what Wood, the professor at the University of Oregon, called “an all-star cast” of fact witnesses.

The afternoon testimony opened with Steve Running, a white-haired man in a gray suit who joked he might be the oldest person in the courtroom. Running, who shared the 2007 Nobel Peace Prize for his work with the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change, testified that science has established that the burning of fossil fuels releases greenhouse gases, which warm the planet and harm the plaintiffs. “Every additional tonne of CO2 matters to the whole world and definitely matters to these plaintiffs,” he said. When asked if the executive orders would make the youth’s injuries worse, Running answered, “Unquestionably.”

Excitement was palpable in the courtroom as Olson called John Podesta to the stand. Podesta was an adviser for former president Joe Biden on clean energy and climate policy when Juliana was in pretrial motions. He and the Biden administration took the position that the argument in Juliana was too broad to implement, so his appearance here was striking.

Olson asked Podesta to explain how executive orders were created and administered. Then she said: “Mr. Podesta, is it fair to say that if an executive order is enjoined, that [government officials] could ensure implementation of that court-ordered injunction?” she asked.

“It would be incumbent on every agent of the federal government who has taken an oath of office to abide by that order, up to and including the president,” he answered. In cross-examination, Sawyer, of the DOJ, worked to get to the heart of the government’s defense — that the plaintiffs are asking the court to weigh into a policy debate. “President Biden also issued day one executive orders, right?” he asked.

Podesta nodded. “Yes.”

Sawyer led Podesta through a series of questions about Biden’s executive order, which compelled the executive branch agencies to take actions geared toward addressing climate change — and which one of Trump’s orders revoked. Sawyer’s main point was to make the case that signing executive orders that revoke a prior administration’s policies and establish new ones is just something that presidents do.

When court recessed for the day, the young plaintiffs chatted warmly with the experts as they exited, thanking them for their support. All the experts had testified for free. On the second day of the hearing, dawn broke brightly, the sun rising over the golden hills surrounding Missoula. In the court room, the young plaintiffs stood in the rows of wooden benches, chatting and laughing quietly as the lawyers hustled to take their seats. The witnesses included an energy economist, a pediatrician, and one more young person.

In her closing arguments, Olson attempted again to draw distinctions between Lighthiser and Juliana, and underscore the injuries that her clients are experiencing, which, she argues, are being worsened by the government’s actions. The judge jumped in. “What is it that you want me to do?”

“The remedy is a simple one,” Olson answered. “It’s enjoining the government from implementing the three executive orders and the specific provisions within them that we have alleged are infringing the plaintiffs’ rights.” The judge expressed concern that a ruling in their favor would lead to an ongoing judicial monitoring of the administration’s actions.

“Your Honor, it’s not about policy choices,” Olson countered. “The Supreme Court has said, in case after case after case, that the fundamental rights to life and liberty don’t get put to a vote. If policymakers could decide to threaten children’s lives, then the Bill of Rights would mean nothing.”

In the government’s closing arguments, Sawyer said the judge was correct to be concerned about wading into a policy issue that should be addressed by Congress and the executive branch. Linking government actions to the rights to life and liberty is, he warned, “a one-way ratchet for safety-ism.”

Judge Christensen has not indicated when he will rule on the plaintiffs’ motion for a preliminary injunction, which would put the executive orders on hold until there is a trial to decide the case. The defendants have also filed a motion to dismiss that is before the court.

According to Mat Dos Santos, co-director of Our Children’s Trust, all the youth climate cases, including Lighthiser, aim to place bumpers on government action — like in a bowling alley — so governments are nudged into taking greenhouse gases and kid’s lives and health into account whenever they set policies.

The key question facing the judge, according to Michael Gerrard, the director of the Sabin Center for Climate Change Law at Columbia University, is whether there is a constitutional basis for the court to act. Striking down executive orders “can be done in a proper case if there is a legal basis for it,” Gerrard said.

Miko Vergun, for one, is still hopeful. “I’m just waiting for good news, to be honest,” she said.

This represents an inspiring example of youth activism and legal innovation to hold governments accountable for climate harms.
articles.personality_title: Youth-led lawsuit challenges Trump’s fossil fuel orders to protect constitutional rights
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Young people have been using the courts to fight against government actions that support fossil fuels and harm the environment. A famous case called Juliana v. United States started in 2015, asking the government to act on climate change. Although that case ended in 2023, youth climate activists continue their legal efforts.

**What happened** – This year, a group of young plaintiffs, including Miko Vergun from the Juliana case, joined a new lawsuit called Lighthiser v. Trump. They are challenging three executive orders signed by former President Trump that encourage more oil, gas, and coal use. The lawsuit, held in Montana in September 2023, focused on stopping these orders because they worsen climate change and harm the plaintiffs’ rights to life and liberty.

**Impact** – This new case asks the court for a smaller, direct action: to block the specific executive orders instead of demanding a full climate plan. Young plaintiffs shared personal stories of health problems and climate disasters linked to fossil fuel pollution. Experts, including Nobel Prize winner Steve Running, confirmed that these orders increase harm. This case shows a fresh legal strategy to hold the government accountable for climate damage while focusing on protecting young people’s constitutional rights.

**What’s next step** – The judge has not yet decided whether to temporarily stop the executive orders while the case continues. The government has also asked the court to dismiss the lawsuit. The outcome will clarify if courts can block government actions that threaten constitutional rights because of climate harm. Meanwhile, the youth and their lawyers remain hopeful and ready to continue fighting.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Young plaintiffs are using a new legal approach to stop government orders that promote fossil fuels, aiming to protect their constitutional rights from climate harm.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des jeunes contestent les ordres exécutifs de Trump sur les combustibles fossiles pour protéger leurs droits constitutionnels
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Depuis plusieurs années, des jeunes utilisent la justice pour s’opposer aux actions gouvernementales qui soutiennent les combustibles fossiles et nuisent à l’environnement. L’affaire célèbre Juliana contre États-Unis, lancée en 2015, demandait au gouvernement d’agir contre le changement climatique. Bien que cette affaire se soit terminée en 2023, les jeunes militants du climat poursuivent leurs efforts juridiques.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Cette année, un groupe de jeunes plaignants, dont Miko Vergun de l’affaire Juliana, a rejoint un nouveau procès nommé Lighthiser contre Trump. Ils contestent trois ordres exécutifs signés par l’ancien président Trump qui encouragent davantage l’utilisation du pétrole, du gaz et du charbon. Le procès, tenu dans le Montana en septembre 2023, vise à bloquer ces ordres parce qu’ils aggravent le changement climatique et portent atteinte aux droits à la vie et à la liberté des plaignants.

**Impact** – Cette nouvelle affaire demande au tribunal une action plus ciblée : empêcher l’application de ces ordres spécifiques au lieu d’exiger un plan climatique complet. Les jeunes plaignants ont raconté leurs problèmes de santé et les catastrophes climatiques liés à la pollution des combustibles fossiles. Des experts, dont le prix Nobel Steve Running, ont confirmé que ces ordres augmentent les dommages. Cette affaire montre une nouvelle stratégie juridique pour tenir le gouvernement responsable des dégâts climatiques tout en protégeant les droits constitutionnels des jeunes.

**Étape suivante** – Le juge n’a pas encore décidé s’il suspend temporairement les ordres exécutifs pendant la poursuite du procès. Le gouvernement a aussi demandé à rejeter la plainte. Le résultat clarifiera si les tribunaux peuvent bloquer des actions gouvernementales menaçant les droits constitutionnels à cause du climat. En attendant, les jeunes et leurs avocats restent optimistes et prêts à continuer le combat.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Des jeunes utilisent une nouvelle stratégie juridique pour arrêter des ordres gouvernementaux favorisant les combustibles fossiles, afin de protéger leurs droits constitutionnels face aux dommages climatiques.
articles.personality_title_es: Jóvenes demandan las órdenes de Trump sobre combustibles fósiles para proteger derechos constitucionales
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Desde hace años, jóvenes han usado los tribunales para oponerse a acciones gubernamentales que apoyan los combustibles fósiles y dañan el medio ambiente. El caso famoso Juliana contra Estados Unidos, iniciado en 2015, pedía al gobierno que actuara contra el cambio climático. Aunque ese caso terminó en 2023, los activistas jóvenes continúan sus esfuerzos legales.

**Qué pasó** – Este año, un grupo de jóvenes demandantes, incluida Miko Vergun del caso Juliana, se unió a una nueva demanda llamada Lighthiser contra Trump. Están impugnando tres órdenes ejecutivas firmadas por el expresidente Trump que fomentan más uso de petróleo, gas y carbón. El juicio, realizado en Montana en septiembre de 2023, buscó detener estas órdenes porque empeoran el cambio climático y dañan los derechos constitucionales de vida y libertad de los demandantes.

**Impacto** – Este nuevo caso pide al tribunal una acción más concreta: bloquear las órdenes específicas en lugar de exigir un plan climático completo. Los jóvenes contaron historias personales de problemas de salud y desastres climáticos ligados a la contaminación de combustibles fósiles. Expertos, incluido el ganador del Nobel Steve Running, confirmaron que estas órdenes aumentan el daño. Este caso muestra una estrategia legal nueva para responsabilizar al gobierno por daños climáticos y proteger los derechos constitucionales de los jóvenes.

**Próximo paso** – El juez aún no ha decidido si suspende temporalmente las órdenes mientras continúa el caso. El gobierno también pidió desestimar la demanda. El resultado aclarará si los tribunales pueden bloquear acciones gubernamentales que amenazan derechos constitucionales por daños climáticos. Mientras tanto, los jóvenes y sus abogados siguen con esperanza y listos para continuar.

**Resumen en una frase** – Jóvenes usan una nueva estrategia legal para detener órdenes gubernamentales que promueven combustibles fósiles y proteger sus derechos constitucionales frente a daños climáticos.

articles.title: On Mental Health Day, End Coercion, Embrace Dignity
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Kaola Baird racing with teammates at the Dragon Boat Race Festival in September 2021. Baird works in Toronto as a fitness instructor and yoga coach who supports others through their path in mental health recovery.
                    © 2021 Samer Muscati/Human Rights Watch
          
    


  
Hauwa, a 25-year-old woman, was lying on the floor, shackled, and barely alive when Human Rights Watch found her in November 2024 in a state-run institution in Kano, Nigeria. She was deaf and had a mental health condition. She died a day later.Human Rights Watch has documented coercive mental healthcare practices, including shackling  people with mental health conditions, in more than 60 countries across the world. Thousands of people with mental health conditions are confined in their homes or in public or private institutions, including rehabilitation, traditional, and faith-based healing centers. articles.content:
Click to expand Image Kaola Baird racing with teammates at the Dragon Boat Race Festival in September 2021. Baird works in Toronto as a fitness instructor and yoga coach who supports others through their path in mental health recovery. © 2021 Samer Muscati/Human Rights Watch

Hauwa, a 25-year-old woman, was lying on the floor, shackled, and barely alive when Human Rights Watch found her in November 2024 in a state-run institution in Kano, Nigeria. She was deaf and had a mental health condition. She died a day later.

Human Rights Watch has documented coercive mental healthcare practices, including shackling people with mental health conditions, in more than 60 countries across the world. Thousands of people with mental health conditions are confined in their homes or in public or private institutions, including rehabilitation, traditional, and faith-based healing centers. These widespread abuses demand urgent action to dismantle coercive systems and replace them with rights-based mental health care.

On World Mental Health Day, all governments should commit to moving away from coercive mental healthcare practices.

The World Health Organization has acknowledged that coercive practices in mental healthcare services remain pervasive and deeply problematic. Among these, it highlights the harmful impact of practices like shackling, noting that these interventions can be traumatic and detrimental to recovery and discourage people from seeking mental health support in the future. Accordingly, governments should replace these coercive responses with mental healthcare services that prioritize autonomy, dignity, and choice.

Non-coercive, effective, and human rights-based mental healthcare models exist and should be used instead. In 2023, Human Rights Watch in partnership with the Toronto Gerstein Crisis Centre, documented some examples of good practices. The Gerstein Crisis Centre’s model provides immediate help both to people with mental health conditions and those who are experiencing acute mental health distress. The staff actively listens and provides a safe space where people can access individual support, feel secure, calm down, regain control, and decide how to move forward.

More comprehensive models are needed to address the combined effects of exclusion and other social factors. These include discrimination as well as social, physical, and emotional factors that prevent people with mental health conditions from fully enjoying their rights. New models should account for the person’s basic needs, such as housing.

Everyone, including those with mental health conditions, deserves access to quality and rights-respecting healthcare services that enable them to make their own health decisions and to be treated with dignity.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights the urgent need to end coercive mental healthcare practices worldwide and promotes the adoption of rights-based, non-coercive mental health care models that prioritize dignity, autonomy, and choice. It references documented abuses and advocates for systemic change with examples of effective alternatives, addressing a significant human rights issue affecting millions globally.
articles.personality_title: Ending harmful mental health practices: A move toward dignity and choice
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Many people with mental health conditions around the world face harmful treatment. Some are locked up, shackled, or forced into care against their will. These practices can hurt recovery and stop people from asking for help.

**What happened** – Human Rights Watch found that in over 60 countries, people with mental health issues are treated with coercion, such as being tied up or kept in institutions without choice. For example, Hauwa, a young woman in Nigeria who was deaf and had a mental health condition, was found shackled and very ill, and she died shortly after. On World Mental Health Day, experts and organizations called for governments to stop these harmful treatments.

**Impact** – The World Health Organization agrees that these coercive treatments cause trauma and harm recovery. They also make people afraid to seek help in the future. Instead, there are better ways to support mental health that respect people’s rights, dignity, and choices. For example, the Toronto Gerstein Crisis Centre offers quick, respectful help where people feel safe and can decide what happens next.

**What's next step** – Governments are encouraged to replace coercive care with these respectful, rights-based models. New approaches should also consider problems like discrimination and lack of housing, which affect mental health. The goal is for everyone with mental health conditions to get care that respects their decisions and treats them with dignity.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Moving away from forced mental health treatments to respectful, supportive care helps people recover with dignity and control over their own lives.
articles.personality_title_fr: Mettre fin aux pratiques néfastes en santé mentale : vers la dignité et le choix
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Dans le monde, beaucoup de personnes souffrant de troubles mentaux subissent des traitements nuisibles. Certaines sont enfermées, enchaînées ou forcées à recevoir des soins contre leur volonté. Ces pratiques peuvent nuire à la guérison et empêcher les gens de demander de l’aide.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Human Rights Watch a découvert que dans plus de 60 pays, des personnes avec des troubles mentaux sont traitées de manière coercitive, comme être attachées ou enfermées sans choix. Par exemple, Hauwa, une jeune femme au Nigeria, sourde et avec un trouble mental, a été retrouvée enchaînée et très malade, puis est morte peu après. À l’occasion de la Journée mondiale de la santé mentale, des experts ont demandé aux gouvernements d’arrêter ces traitements nuisibles.

**Impact** – L’Organisation mondiale de la santé reconnaît que ces traitements coercitifs causent des traumatismes et ralentissent la guérison. Ils font aussi peur aux personnes de demander de l’aide à l’avenir. Il existe pourtant de meilleures méthodes qui respectent les droits, la dignité et les choix des personnes. Par exemple, le Centre de crise Gerstein à Toronto offre une aide rapide et respectueuse où chacun peut se sentir en sécurité et décider de la suite.

**Prochaine étape** – Les gouvernements sont invités à remplacer les soins forcés par ces modèles respectueux des droits. Les nouvelles approches doivent aussi prendre en compte la discrimination et le manque de logement, qui influencent la santé mentale. Le but est que toutes les personnes avec des troubles mentaux reçoivent des soins qui respectent leurs décisions et leur dignité.

**Une phrase à retenir** – Passer des traitements forcés à des soins respectueux et soutenants aide les personnes à guérir avec dignité et contrôle sur leur vie.
articles.personality_title_es: Poner fin a prácticas dañinas en salud mental: hacia la dignidad y la elección
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – En todo el mundo, muchas personas con problemas de salud mental sufren tratamientos dañinos. Algunas son encerradas, encadenadas o forzadas a recibir atención sin su consentimiento. Estas prácticas pueden dificultar la recuperación y evitar que pidan ayuda.

**Qué pasó** – Human Rights Watch descubrió que en más de 60 países, personas con problemas mentales son tratadas con coerción, como ser atadas o recluidas sin opción. Por ejemplo, Hauwa, una joven en Nigeria que era sorda y tenía un problema mental, fue encontrada encadenada y muy enferma, y murió poco después. En el Día Mundial de la Salud Mental, expertos pidieron a los gobiernos que detengan estos tratamientos perjudiciales.

**Impacto** – La Organización Mundial de la Salud reconoce que estas prácticas coercitivas causan trauma y dificultan la recuperación. También hacen que las personas tengan miedo de buscar ayuda en el futuro. Sin embargo, existen mejores formas de apoyar la salud mental que respetan los derechos, la dignidad y las decisiones de las personas. Por ejemplo, el Centro de Crisis Gerstein en Toronto ofrece ayuda rápida y respetuosa donde las personas se sienten seguras y pueden decidir qué hacer a continuación.

**Próximo paso** – Se anima a los gobiernos a reemplazar el cuidado coercitivo por estos modelos respetuosos y basados en derechos. Las nuevas soluciones también deben considerar la discriminación y la falta de vivienda, que afectan la salud mental. El objetivo es que todas las personas con problemas mentales reciban atención que respete sus decisiones y las trate con dignidad.

**Una frase para recordar** – Cambiar los tratamientos forzados por cuidados respetuosos y solidarios ayuda a las personas a recuperarse con dignidad y control sobre sus vidas.

articles.title: In Bangladesh a Step toward Justice
articles.summary:
Click to expand Image
          



  
        
  

        
                      
      
        
              Chief Advisor Muhammad Yunus (3rd L) visits three secret detention facilities known as "Ayna Ghor," which had been used as torture cells during the Awami League government's rule, Dhaka, Bangladesh, February 12, 2025.
                    © 2025 Nayem Shaan/Drik/Getty Images
          
    


  
On October 9, the Bangladesh authorities filed charges against 28 people  for enforced disappearances, secret detention, and torture. It was a long time coming.A “smear campaign,” the home minister had scoffed in 2017, after Human Rights Watch released a report on secret detentions and enforced disappearances in Bangladesh. When I had met with him, the minister, Asaduzzaman Khan, had been dismissive, saying that most of the “disappeared” were criminals evading arrest, debt dodgers, or adulterers. He agreed to investigate at my insistence, but that never happened. During its time in office from 2009 to 2024, the Sheikh Hasina administration, of which Khan was a key member, became increasingly authoritarian. Our work on extrajudicial killings, torture, and suppression of speech was met with denials or false promises.The repression persisted until August 2024, when the Hasina government was toppled following three weeks of enraged protests in which 1,400 people were killed. Hasina, Khan, and several senior officials fled the country. An interim government, led by Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel peace laureate, came in promising reforms. It established a Commission of Inquiry on Enforced Disappearances, which received at least 1,850 complaints, and found that over 300 victims  were presumed killed in custody. The commission recently released a documentary “Unfolding the Truth” describing its findings, including horrifying accounts of cruelty. Hasina and Khan were among those charged on October 9, as were several army officers, both former and serving.Among those in court when the charges were announced were people whose cases we had documented. One is Mir Ahmad Bin Quasem, or Armaan as he is called, who had chillingly written to me just days before his disappearance in 2016 that he was “worried” about his own safety. He was held for eight years in a secret military intelligence detention site,  and was released after the Hasina government was deposed. Over those years, his wife would call me, desperate for news – the plight of so many families of the disappeared who keep waiting for miracles. Armaan recently told me he is well and had written a book. As human rights workers, we too wait for such miracles. Yet, too often, human rights abuses persist. The accused will be prosecuted by the Bangladesh International Crimes Tribunal, but concerns remain about ensuring fair trial standards and the use of the death penalty.
articles.content:
Click to expand Image Chief Advisor Muhammad Yunus (3rd L) visits three secret detention facilities known as "Ayna Ghor," which had been used as torture cells during the Awami League government's rule, Dhaka, Bangladesh, February 12, 2025. © 2025 Nayem Shaan/Drik/Getty Images

On October 9, the Bangladesh authorities filed charges against 28 people for enforced disappearances, secret detention, and torture. It was a long time coming.

A “smear campaign,” the home minister had scoffed in 2017, after Human Rights Watch released a report on secret detentions and enforced disappearances in Bangladesh. When I had met with him, the minister, Asaduzzaman Khan, had been dismissive, saying that most of the “disappeared” were criminals evading arrest, debt dodgers, or adulterers. He agreed to investigate at my insistence, but that never happened.

During its time in office from 2009 to 2024, the Sheikh Hasina administration, of which Khan was a key member, became increasingly authoritarian. Our work on extrajudicial killings, torture, and suppression of speech was met with denials or false promises.

The repression persisted until August 2024, when the Hasina government was toppled following three weeks of enraged protests in which 1,400 people were killed. Hasina, Khan, and several senior officials fled the country.

An interim government, led by Muhammad Yunus, a Nobel peace laureate, came in promising reforms. It established a Commission of Inquiry on Enforced Disappearances, which received at least 1,850 complaints, and found that over 300 victims were presumed killed in custody. The commission recently released a documentary “Unfolding the Truth” describing its findings, including horrifying accounts of cruelty.

Hasina and Khan were among those charged on October 9, as were several army officers, both former and serving.

Among those in court when the charges were announced were people whose cases we had documented. One is Mir Ahmad Bin Quasem, or Armaan as he is called, who had chillingly written to me just days before his disappearance in 2016 that he was “worried” about his own safety. He was held for eight years in a secret military intelligence detention site , and was released after the Hasina government was deposed.

Over those years, his wife would call me, desperate for news – the plight of so many families of the disappeared who keep waiting for miracles. Armaan recently told me he is well and had written a book.

As human rights workers, we too wait for such miracles. Yet, too often, human rights abuses persist. The accused will be prosecuted by the Bangladesh International Crimes Tribunal, but concerns remain about ensuring fair trial standards and the use of the death penalty.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant step toward justice in Bangladesh with the filing of charges against 28 individuals, including former government officials, for enforced disappearances, secret detention, and torture. This development follows years of repression and marks a meaningful move toward accountability and reform under a new interim government led by a Nobel laureate. The story has broad significance for human rights and justice in Bangladesh, with detailed context and real-world impact for victims and society.
articles.personality_title: Bangladesh files charges to end secret detentions and torture
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – For many years, Bangladesh faced serious problems with secret arrests, disappearances, and torture. The government led by Sheikh Hasina from 2009 to 2024 was accused of hiding these abuses and refusing to investigate them.

**What happened** – On October 9, 2025, the new Bangladeshi authorities charged 28 people, including former leaders and army officers, for enforced disappearances, secret detention, and torture. This came after the previous government was removed in August 2024 following deadly protests. An interim government led by Nobel Peace Prize winner Muhammad Yunus set up a commission that collected many complaints and found over 300 victims likely killed in custody.

**Impact** – This is a rare and important move toward justice in Bangladesh. For years, families waited for answers about their missing loved ones, like Mir Ahmad Bin Quasem, who was held in secret for eight years and recently freed. The charges show a serious effort to hold powerful people accountable for past abuses.

**What's next step** – The accused will face trial at the Bangladesh International Crimes Tribunal. People hope these trials will be fair, but there are worries about the use of the death penalty and court procedures. The government plans to continue reforms to protect human rights.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Bangladesh’s new government has taken a strong step by charging former officials with secret detentions and torture, aiming to bring justice to victims and their families.
articles.personality_title_fr: Le Bangladesh engage des poursuites contre les disparitions secrètes et la torture
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Pendant de nombreuses années, le Bangladesh a été confronté à de graves problèmes d'arrestations secrètes, de disparitions et de torture. Le gouvernement dirigé par Sheikh Hasina de 2009 à 2024 a été accusé de cacher ces abus et de refuser de les enquêter.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 9 octobre 2025, les nouvelles autorités bangladaises ont inculpé 28 personnes, dont d'anciens dirigeants et des officiers de l'armée, pour disparitions forcées, détentions secrètes et torture. Cela est arrivé après que l'ancien gouvernement a été renversé en août 2024 suite à des manifestations meurtrières. Un gouvernement intérimaire dirigé par le lauréat du prix Nobel de la paix Muhammad Yunus a créé une commission qui a reçu de nombreuses plaintes et a conclu que plus de 300 victimes ont probablement été tuées en détention.

**Impact** – C'est une démarche rare et importante vers la justice au Bangladesh. Pendant des années, les familles attendaient des réponses sur leurs proches disparus, comme Mir Ahmad Bin Quasem, détenu secrètement pendant huit ans et récemment libéré. Ces accusations montrent un effort sérieux pour tenir les personnes puissantes responsables des abus passés.

**Prochaine étape** – Les accusés seront jugés par le Tribunal international des crimes du Bangladesh. On espère que ces procès seront équitables, mais des inquiétudes subsistent concernant la peine de mort et les procédures judiciaires. Le gouvernement prévoit de poursuivre les réformes pour protéger les droits humains.

**Résumé en une phrase** – Le nouveau gouvernement du Bangladesh a pris une mesure forte en inculpant d'anciens responsables pour détentions secrètes et torture, visant à rendre justice aux victimes et à leurs familles.
articles.personality_title_es: Bangladesh presenta cargos por detenciones secretas y tortura
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Durante muchos años, Bangladesh tuvo graves problemas con arrestos secretos, desapariciones y torturas. El gobierno de Sheikh Hasina entre 2009 y 2024 fue acusado de ocultar estos abusos y negarse a investigarlos.

**Qué pasó** – El 9 de octubre de 2025, las nuevas autoridades de Bangladesh presentaron cargos contra 28 personas, incluidos exlíderes y oficiales del ejército, por desapariciones forzadas, detenciones secretas y tortura. Esto ocurrió después de que el gobierno anterior fuera destituido en agosto de 2024 tras protestas violentas. Un gobierno interino liderado por el ganador del Premio Nobel de la Paz, Muhammad Yunus, estableció una comisión que recibió muchas denuncias y concluyó que más de 300 víctimas probablemente murieron bajo custodia.

**Impacto** – Este es un paso raro e importante hacia la justicia en Bangladesh. Durante años, las familias esperaron respuestas sobre sus seres queridos desaparecidos, como Mir Ahmad Bin Quasem, que estuvo detenido en secreto por ocho años y fue liberado recientemente. Los cargos muestran un esfuerzo serio para responsabilizar a personas poderosas por abusos pasados.

**Próximo paso** – Los acusados serán juzgados en el Tribunal Internacional de Crímenes de Bangladesh. Se espera que los juicios sean justos, aunque hay preocupaciones sobre la pena de muerte y los procedimientos judiciales. El gobierno planea continuar con reformas para proteger los derechos humanos.

**Resumen en una frase** – El nuevo gobierno de Bangladesh ha dado un paso firme al acusar a exfuncionarios por detenciones secretas y tortura, buscando justicia para las víctimas y sus familias.
